description:
Colletotrichum fioriniae is a fungal plant pathogen that belongs to the genus Colletotrichum, a group of economically important fungal species responsible for various diseases in a wide range of agricultural crops. This species was first identified and described in 2016, and it is known to cause anthracnose disease in several hosts, including strawberry, apple, and blueberry.

Colletotrichum fioriniae is a hemibiotrophic fungus, meaning it transitions from a biotrophic phase, where it feeds on living host cells, to a necrotrophic phase, where it kills and consumes host cells. The fungus produces dark-colored, acervulus-type fruiting bodies on the surface of infected plant tissues, which release asexual spores (conidia) that can spread the disease to other plants.

The identification and characterization of Colletotrichum fioriniae have been important for understanding the diversity and host specificity within the Colletotrichum genus, as well as for developing effective management strategies to control anthracnose diseases in various agricultural systems.
